resource.name: equivalence_validation_of_product_data
resource.keywords: Product data equivalence, Product shape data equivalence, Assembly data equivalence, PMI data equivalence, Criteria representation, Inspection requirement, Threshold, Accuracy , Inspection result representation

abstract.p: This part of ISO 10303 provides structured representation of criteria together with inspection requirement, and inspection results for the equivalence validation of product data. It is designed for use in equivalence declaration, equivalence assurance and for representing equivalence inspection result of product data, thus enabling equivalence guaranteed use of product data

purpose.p: Before going into details of equivalence validation, it will be appropriate to discuss why equivalence validation of product data is required. All product model data are created by some CAD system and it is well known that created product data frequently travels two or more different IT systems to conduct expected applications in various types of design, simulation, manufacturing preparation, etc. For travelling from an IT system to other IT system, data conversion by the use of STEP translator, or other types of translators is required. As is well known, numerical representation method and satisfied precision are IT system dependent. Therefore, data conversion may cause slight difference of data. For users of the data, whether or not the difference of data caused by the conversion is acceptable for the applications expected to be conducted for the converted data is critically important, since it concerns with the reliability of the data. The check to validate whether or not the difference between the original data and the converted data is acceptable is “Equivalence Validation”. This part of ISO 10303 deals with this equivalence validation for product data.

It shall be noted that the comparison for checking equivalence is not conducted for arbitrary selected two product data, but conducted for the two product data where one is obtained from the other by data conversion. Therefore, there is an assumption that the two product data are not very different but are similar from various points of view.

There are various constituent data types of product data. In this edition of ISO 10303, shape data equivalence, assembly data equivalence, and PMI data equivalence are targets of equivalence validation. Equivalence of other constituents of product data will be dealt with in the future editions.

This part of ISO 10303 consists of five mutually related schemas as shown in Figure 1. The first schema, namely the product data equivalence definition schema, defines high level data elements for managing product data equivalence information such as the relationship of the product data equivalence information with the pertaining product data inspected. The second schema, namely the product data equivalence criteria schema, deals with general product data and specifies how to represent equivalence criteria and equivalence inspection requirements. The third schema, namely the product data equivalence inspection result schema, also deals with general product data and specifies how to represent equivalence inspection results. Specifications defined in the second and the third schemas are sufficiently general so that equivalence of various types of product data other than shape data, assembly data and PMI data can be dealt with in the future.

Two schemas, the annotated model 3d equivalence criteria schema and the annotated model 3d equivalence inspection result schema are specializations of the product data equivalence criteria schema and the product data equivalence inspection result schema respectively to annotated model 3d data. The equivalence of annotated model 3d data is further classified into Shape data equivalence, Assembly data equivalence, and PMI equivalence, that are standardized in detail in the annotated_model_3d_equivalence_shape_module, annotated_model_3d_equivalence_assembly module and annotated_model_3d_equivalence_PMI module respectively.

The target product shape data representation is limited in this part of ISO 10303 to the data conforming to ISO 10303-42, and some APs based on ISO 10303-42. The target assembly data representation also is limited to ISO 10303 relevant representation though the treatment of leaf component part shape representation is similar to that of ISO 10303-242. The target PMI data presentation and representation is similar to ISO 10303-242.

Each criterion for equivalence validation may include a pertaining inspection requirement. An inspection requirement provides a textual description of how the criterion is to be inspected and may have additional attributes and rules to control the test and the element or elements to be tested. It does not provide an algorithm for the inspection process. It is expected that the developer of a product data validation checking program will develop his algorithm for the inspection so that that algorithm satisfies the inspection requirement specified.
purpose.note: Inspection algorithms are outside the scope of this part of ISO 10303 since it is understood that algorithm development is a competitive arena for engineering system vendors and cannot be standardized by an international standard.
purpose.p: For the assessment of equivalence validation by numerical test, thresholds which are user definable from application protocols supporting above described shape, assembly and PMI data representations, such as ISO 10303-242[1], play a key role. An example of a typical threshold is a distance threshold for validating the maximum deviation of the original and converted product data. That distance threshold implies that if the maximum distance between corresponding position of the two product data is greater than or equal to the specified minimum value, then the deviation shall be understood as unacceptable deviation. Appropriate thresholds depend on many factors such as size of a product, design requirements, sensitivity of engineering systems to numerical imprecision, etc. Therefore, what threshold value to use needs to be carefully determined in each business situation based on agreement among business partners.

The product data equivalence inspection result schema provides representation of equivalence inspection results for two specified product data with regard to specified equivalence criteria. The inspection result indicates whether or not the two product data inspected contain unacceptable difference. It may also include detailed information on what type of unacceptable difference is existing, and how serious the difference is, together with the product data element where the problem is detected. This information is expected to be useful for the equivalence improvement process.

Figure I.1 denotes the model structure of five schemas and the relationship with the target product data. Figure I.2 denotes more detailed relationship of top three schemas, that are product_data_equivalence_definition schema, product_data_equivalence_criteria schema, and product_data_equivalence_inspection_result schema. Together with five schemas in this standard, six modules are constituents of equivalence validation standards, that are ;
Figure I.3 shows top three modules.

figure.title: Relationship between equivalence validation schemas and target product data
EXPRESS-G diagram of the model structure of the top three equivalence validation schemas
Relationship between equivalence validation modules and target product data

purpose.note: Numbers enclosed in triangles in Figure 2 denote internal references within the figure. This is not standard EXPRESS-G style but is used to prevent complicated long path references.
purpose.p: Constituent schemas of this part of ISO 10303 are as follows:

ul.li: Product_data_equivalence_definition schema: defines high level data elements for managing product data equivalence validation information;

Product_data_equivalence_criteria schema: provides general specifications for the representation of equivalence validation criteria, equivalence inspection requirements and equivalence assessment specifications for product data;
Product_data_equivalence_inspection_result schema: provides general specifications for the representation of equivalence inspection results for a particular couple of product data;

Annotate_mode_3d_equivalence_criteria schema: provides representations of equivalence validation criteria for annotated model 3d data. together with the pertaining inspection requirements, assessment specifications and thresholds for judging whether or not equivalence is satisfied;

Annotated_model_3d_inspection_result schema: provides representations of equivalence inspection results for a particular couple of product data with regard to specified equivalence criteria. Detailed information on what type of non-equivalence is existing, and how serious it is, together with the product element data where the problem is detected can also be represented.

imgfile.title: Schema level diagram of relationships among ISO 10303-62 schemas (inside the box) and with other resource schemas

resource.scope: This part of ISO 10303 specifies representation of product data equivalence validation information especially focusing on annotated model 3d data. It provides general specifications for the representation of equivalence validation criterion, equivalence inspection requirement, equivalence assessment specification and equivalence inspection result of product data. These specifications are provided so that this part of ISO 10303 can be extended to deal with other constituents of product data than annotated model 3d data in the future. By focusing on annotated model 3d data, detailed specifications for the representation of equivalence validation criterion together with the pertaining inspection requirement, equivalence assessment specification and detailed result of annotated model 3d equivalence inspection are provided.

inscope.li: representation of high level data elements for managing equivalence validation related data;
representation of general equivalence validation criteria for product data;
representation of general equivalence validation criteria for product data associated to the corresponding validation inspection requirements;
representation of general equivalence validation criteria for product data associated to the corresponding assessment specifications;
representation of equivalence validation results of given two product data;

representation of equivalence validation criteria for three dimensional annotated product model data coupled with inspection requirements for the evaluation of equivalence validation criteria and association with the pertinent assessment specifications. Equivalence validation criteria can be used for the representation of requirement, declaration of, or assurance of, equivalence validation of two three dimensional annotated product model data. The target shape data models are equivalent to those defined in ISO 10303-42 or application protocol based on that;
representation of equivalence validation results of the given two three dimensional annotated product model data.
inscope.note: Requirements of product data equivalence is application context-dependent. This part of ISO 10303 provides a means to select appropriate criteria with required thresholds.

outscope.li: detailed information relating to equivalence validation of product data other than three dimensional annotated product model data; Though general specifications for the representation of criterion, inspection requirement, assessment specification and inspection result of product data are given, detailed specifications are provided only for annotated model 3d data.
data model to improve equivalence of three dimensional annotated product data;
process model to ensure equivalence of product data.

schema.name: product_data_equivalence_definition_schema
schema.fund_cons:
This schema provides the following information;
identification and definition of product data equivalence information.
It is understood that equivalence validation information is not a constituent of a product data. In case some designed product data converted from other product data is inspected whether or not it is equivalent with the original product data , then the inspection results will be created relating to a particular couple of product data. Therefore, equivalence validation information shall be identified and defined separately from a product definition with relationship to the pertaining product definitions as necessary.
relationship between product data equivalence information and product data.
This relationship is required to represent inspection results of a particular couple of product data. Actual relationship will be created between an equivalence definition entity and a couple of product definition entities.
Existence of a data equivalence definition entity implies the existence of a set of product data equivalence criteria. Related inspection results may also exist. The product data equivalence criteria are represented using entities defined in product_data_equivalence_criteria_schema and the inspection results are represented using entities defined in product_data_equivalence_inspection_result_schema.

fund_cons.p: In order to unambiguously share product data equivalence information, the following are required:

ol.li: A clear statement of each equivalence requirement. Such a requirement will be referred to as a ‘equivalence criterion’ in this standard;

Specification of necessary conditions for the inspection to be used for ensuring that equivalence criteria are met. Such conditions are referred to as ‘inspection requirement’ in this standard. Each inspection requirement shall specify the types of entities to be checked, the inspection process to be used (if definable), and the required accuracy of the inspection. Inspection processes are specified in descriptive terms only — the actual inspection algorithms are outside the scope of this standard;

Specification of criteria for judging the acceptability of the equivalence inspection. Such specifications are referred to as ‘assessment specifications’ in this standard. Assessment specifications for the equivalence of annotated model 3d fall into two classes, the first involving numerical tests with one or two thresholds for acceptability, and the second involving logical tests (details will be presented in clause 7);
A method for the representation of the requirements for reporting on the equivalence of annotated model 3d;
A method for the representation of inspection results;

fund_cons.p: This schema provides representations for items a. – d. in the foregoing list, which are mandatory in any application.
fund_cons.note: Scenarios of the expected use of this standard are described in Annex G.
The information corresponding to e. above is specified in product_data_equivalence_inspection_result_schema.
fund_cons.b: 5.2.1 Representation of product data equivalence criteria
fund_cons.p: Product data equivalence can be unambiguously represented by a combination of equivalence criteria. Each criterion may have one or more associated inspection requirement and assessment specification.

It is anticipated that there are equivalence criteria of which inspection requirement is not possible to clearly specify. For this reason, this schema provides both equivalence criteria with or without relationship to pertaining inspection requirement.
fund_cons.example: ‘implied semantics shall be completely converted’ is a clear and important product data equivalence requirement. In this case, ‘identical implied semantics’ will become a criterion. Therefore, satisfaction of the criterion implies existence of equivalence defect. But, unambiguous specification of identical implied semantics will be quite difficult to define.

Significant deviation between corresponding positions of the two product data will be problematic for receiver side since it will deteriorate reliability of the data. In order to detect this type of non-equivalent data, the criterion ‘ domain_matching_of_arcwise-connected_surfaces’ as defined in the annotated_model_3d_equivalence_shape_module is prepared. In order to judge the equivalence, related inspection shall be based on the calculation of distance between two corresponding surfaces. The distance shall be calculated ideally for any point on a surface as minimum distance to the corresponding surface. After calculating this distance for all points on the surface, maximum value among them shall be obtained. Then this maximum distance shall be compared with the threshold defined for this criterion for evaluating if non-equivalent defect is existing or not. This example shows combination of quality criterion, associated inspection requirement and assessment specification form core part of equivalence validation model representation.
fund_cons.p: Equivalence requirement is application dependent and target design requirement dependent. This schema allows users to select a set of necessary criteria from the standardized criteria and combine them to represent his requirements on product data equivalence.

Specifications in this schema are enough general so that they can be applied for equivalence of any property of a product data. Specialization of this schema to annotated model 3d data is given in clause 7. Specialization to product data equivalence of any property other than annotated model 3d data will also be possible in the future as a specialization of this schema.
fund_cons.b: 5.2.2 Correspondence of data elements to compare
fund_cons.p: Correspondence of data elements to compare, one in the original product model, the other in the converted model shall be exactly known. As for shape model, external specification of correspondence finding algorithm is given in the annotated_model_3d_shape_equivalence module.

As for assembly model and PMI data, it is understood that there is no commonly used method for detecting the correspondence, but the use of user given name when applicable, or bounding box for knowing spatial extent, etc. are used. In the definition of criteria in annotated_model_3d_equivalence_assembly module and annotated_model_3d_equivalence_PMI module, it is assumed that the correspondence is known outside of those standards. If unique naming method such as UUID is developed in the future, it is assumed that unique name will be transferred via STEP translator.
fund_cons.b: 5.2.3 Representation of the requirement on inspection of product data quivalence
fund_cons.p: In order to inspect if a non-equivalent defect is existing or not, reliable inspection shall be associated to each equivalence criterion.
The following are requirements for reliable inspection:

ol.li: Appropriate data element shall be inspected.

Necessary conditions for appropriate inspection shall be clarified such as mandatory inspection process if definable, what physical quantity shall be inspected, what special cases shall be taken into account, required precision of inspection result, etc.
Robust algorithm that satisfies all the requirements represented by 1. above shall be deployed.

fund_cons.p: It is understood that inspection algorithm belongs to competitive arena for engineering system vendors and therefore shall not be standardized by an International Standard. By this reason, requirement 3. above is outside the scope of this standard.
The representation of inspection requirement is designed so that it can be used both for equivalence criteria representation and inspection result representation.

Type of information and level of details of inspection result report may differ depending on the scenario of its use or the purpose of the inspection. The entity data_equivalence_report_request provides the representation of a request for an inspection report with regard to a particular criterion. It has two subtypes, summary_equivalence_report_request and detailed_equivalence_report_request. The use of summary_equivalence_report_request is recommended to capture overall equivalence level such as how many entities were checked regarding the criterion and how many entities among them were judged as having non-equivalent defect. The use of detailed_equivalence_report_request is suited to obtain more detailed report such as what entity instance caused non-equivalent defect and how serious it is. It has attributes to request a report on all the inspected elements or only on elements with non-equivalent defect. Expected number of elements to be reported and expected sequence of report may also be specified. Since these specifications affects to other schemas in this standard, it is recommended to look into Figure 1 of Introduction to understand related entities in other schemas. data_equivalence_inspection_report of product_data_equivalence_inspection_result_schema corresponds to data_equivalence_report_request of this schema. It has two subtypes, data_equivalence_inspection_criterion_report which corresponds to summary_equivalence_report_request of this schema and data_equivalence_inspection_instance_report which corresponds to detailed_equivalence_report_request of this schema. data_equivalence_inspection_instance_report is a collection of data_equivalence_inspection_instance_report_item which corresponds to one instance or one pair of instances of the given product data.
fund_cons.note: In annotated_model_3d_equivalence_inspection_result_schema, data_equivalence_inspection_inspection_instance_report_item is specialized to annotated_model_3d_equivalence_inspection_instance_report_item which has a subtype instance_report_item_with_extreme_instances for representing non-equivalent defect in annotated_model_3d instance level and how serious it is.
fund_cons.example: The following explanation assumes the case where only report on non-equivalent elements is requested. In the case of ‘ domain matching by Gaussian G2 continuity’ criterion as defined in shape_equivalence_module, two or more surfaces may be detected as having non-equivalent defect by losing G2 continuity. The entity data_equivalence_inspection_instance_report (or annotated_model_3d_equivalence_inspection_instance_report) will report all the detected surfaces. The entity data_equivalence_inspection_instance_report_item (or annotated_model_3d_equivalence_inspection_instance_report_item) corresponds to one detected surface.

fund_cons.p: This schema provides general specifications for the representation of equivalence inspection result of product data. Inspection results show the level of product data equivalence of particular couple of product data instance with regard to specified equivalence criteria. Therefore, identification of the product data instances inspected and the relationship to corresponding equivalence criteria specified are provided.

Necessity of inspection results depends on usage scenario of product data equivalence information. When only equivalence requirements are transferred or declaration of satisfied equivalence is transferred, inspection results are not required.
fund_cons.note: See annex G for details on what kind of equivalence related information is required for each expected usage scenario.
fund_cons.p: An instance of data_equivalence_inspection_result represents inspection result corresponding to exactly one data equivalence criterion. There are cases that judgement on whether to regard obtained inspection result as non-equivalent defect or not is application dependent. Therefore, two entities with and without judgement are provided.

To represent entire inspection result corresponding to a set of specified product data equivalence criteria, data_equivalence_inspection_result_representation is provided. It is a collection of data_equivalence_inspection_results. The relationship between the former and the latter is identical with the relationship between representation and representation_item.

As for the inspection result report, there are two types. One is a summary report that represents what equivalence criterion was checked and what were inspection results without going into detail about what entity instance caused what extent of non-equivalent defect. This information will be effectively used for judging equivalence level of the target couple of product data with regard to one criterion. The other is detailed information in entity instance level to represent what particular entity instance caused what kind and degree of non-equivalent defect. This information will be effectively used for improving the equivalence of the target product data instances.

Specifications in this schema are enough general so that they can be applied for the representation of inspection result of any property of a product data. Specialization of this schema to annotated model 3d data is given in clause 8. Specialization to inspection result of any property other than annotated model 3d will also be possible in the future as a specialization of this schema.

This schema provides representation of equivalence criteria for annotated model 3d data. It does not directly define what is good equivalence data but rather classifies and enumerates equivalence concerns for detecting non-equivalent data. This schema is a specialization of product_data_equivalence_criteria_schema presented in clause 5 to the equivalence of annotated model 3d data. Therefore, all the fundamental concepts and assumptions described in 5.2 also apply. This schema provides classified annotated model 3d criteria together with pertaining inspection requirements and thresholds for the assessment of annotated model 3d equivalence. Accuracy is also related to each criterion when appropriate.
fund_cons.b: 7.2.1 Representation of the criteria of annotated model 3d equivalence and its classification
fund_cons.p: The equivalence of annotated model 3d data is modelled in this part of ISO 10303 by classifying them into shape data equivalence, assembly data equivalence and PMI data equivalence. Practical inconveniences which may cause rework in receiver side in order to improve received data usable in receiver’s job. These inconveniences mainly arise due to inappropriate numerical representation or inappropriate numerical manipulation of underlying mathematical model. These inconveniences are highly CAD system dependent. The classification is based on taxonomy of known problems caused by non-equivalent annotated model 3d data.
fund_cons.note: It is understood that good equivalence annotated model 3d data represent design result entirely with acceptable precision where degree of satisfaction of design requirements and design intent is explicitly represented. Though use of 3D engineering systems is expanding, no system fully supports creation and maintenance of good equivalence annotated model 3d data as defined above. Satisfaction of the requirement ‘degree of satisfaction of design requirements and design intent is explicitly represented’ is still a big unresolved research issue.

Shape data of the concerned annotated model 3d data shall be represented using entities defined in ISO 10303-42 or entities defined in AP based on ISO 10303-42. Among various representation methods such as boundary representation (B-Rep) and CSG, boundary representation (B-Rep) are mainly focused.

Detailed criteria are classified as subtypes of annotated_mode_3d_criterion that is a type of data_equivalence_criterion as defined in clause 5: product_data_equivalence_criteria_schema of this part of ISO 10303.
fund_cons.p: Aesthetic quality of product shape is a decisive factor for some type of product such as passenger car. But, rigorous definition of aesthetic quality is not included in this standard since technology for its evaluation is not yet well established though practical functions for its evaluation such as smooth highlight lines or smooth curvature distribution are deployed. Only criteria requiring whether or not smooth free form curves and surfaces are kept in the converted model is included.

It may not be practical to obtain detailed information of inspection results of annotated model 3d equivalence entirely and send them to later stages. annotated_mode_3d_criterion_with_element_report_request is prepared for controlling amount of detailed information so that only necessary amount is obtained.
fund_cons.b: 7.2.2 Representation of the requirement on the inspection of annotated model 3d equivalence
fund_cons.p: Each criterion has an associated inspection requirement. An inspection requirement provides a textual description of how the criterion is to be inspected and may have additional attributes and rules to control the test and the element or elements to be tested. It does not provide an algorithm for the inspection process. It may be said that an inspection requirement plays a role of external specification for reliable inspection algorithm.
fund_cons.b: 7.2.3 Specialization of data equivalence assessment specification
fund_cons.p: data_equivalence_assessment_specification defined in product_data_equivalence_criteria_schema is specialized to annotated model 3d equivalence by annotated_model_3d_assessment_specification in this schema that has two subtypes annotated_model_3d_assessment_by_numerical_test and annotated_model_3d_assessment_by_logical_test. For the assessment of annotated_model_3d_by_numerical_test, attribute thresholds which are user definable from AP (Application Protocol) play a key role. An example of a typical threshold is a distance threshold for evaluating a deviation between corresponding positions of the two product data inspected. That distance threshold implies that maximum distance between the two corresponding arc-wise connected surfaces shall be smaller than the threshold. Appropriate thresholds depend on many factors such as size of a product, design requirements, robustness of engineering systems on numerical precision, etc. Therefore, what threshold value to use shall be carefully determined in each business situation based on agreement among business partners.
fund_cons.b: 7.2.4 Representation of required accuracy for annotated model 3d data equivalence inspection
fund_cons.p: In most cases, especially when free form geometry is involved, the inspection algorithm calculates an approximate solution not an exact solution. In the above example, arc-wise connected surfaces consist of an infinite number of points. Since calculation on an infinite number of points is impossible, any algorithm tries to calculate the solution using a sufficient number of finite points. In order to require the difference of the approximate solution and the exact solution, even when it is unknown, smaller than the expected value, accuracy specification is provided. The accuracy shall be understood that an approximate solution is acceptable if the difference of the approximate solution and other approximate solution obtained by calculation with any other finer sampling points is smaller than the given accuracy. There are two types of accuracies, one is general accuracy applied to all the inspections and the other is specific accuracy applied only to specified inspection.
fund_cons.note: ISO 10303-45 includes qualified_measure_schema where specifications to qualify inspection results of physical object from accuracy point of view are defined. Though there are some similarities between the concept defined in that schema and the accuracy concept defined in this standard, the latter concerns with the accuracy of numerical calculation. It therefore includes accuracy of value without any unit such as accuracy of parameter value that is not taken into account in the qualified_measure_schema. The accuracy information in this standard is effective for representing requirement of accuracy of numerical calculation even when the target product data is not yet identified. These are the reasons why the accuracy concept in this standard makes use of only appropriate portion of the qualified_measure_schema.

Default accuracy applicable to all the inspections is represented by the attribute required_general_accuracy of the entity annotated_model_3d_equivalence_criteria_representation_with_accuracy. The accuracy specific to each inspection can be represented by the attribute required_specific_accuracy of the entity annotated_mode_3d_equivalence_criterion_and_accuracy_association. Actual accuracy applied by equivalence inspection can be represented using entities in the annotated_mode_3d_equivalence_- inspection_result schema.

fund_cons.p: This schema provides representation of inspection results of annotated model 3d equivalence. This schema is a specialization of product_data_equivalence_inspection_result_schema presented in clause 6 to the equivalence of annotated model 3d data. Therefore, all the fundamental concepts and assumptions described in 6.2 also apply.

As this schema deals with inspection result of the equivalence of annotated model 3d data, a relationship is established between annotated_model_3d_equivalence_inspection_result_representation that is a type of data_equivalence_inspection_result_representation defined in product_data_equivalence_inspection_result_schema and representation representing inspection target annotated model 3d data by annotated_model_3d_equivalence_inspected_annotated_model_3d_and_result_relationship.
fund_cons.note: Geometric data newly created for representing inspection results, such as points where non-equivalence defect was detected , shall be created in the context of the inspected product data.
fund_cons.p: Annotated_model_3d_equivalence_inspection_criterion_report that is a type of data_equivalence_inspection_criterion_report defined in product_data_equivalence_inspection_result_schema represents summarized inspection result on a specific annotated model 3d equivalence criterion that includes how many entities were inspected with how many non-equivalent defects as a result. It also includes representative_inspected_value that is a typical inspected value obtained.

Annotated_model_3d_equivalence_inspection_instance_report that is a type of data_equivalence_inspection_instance_report defined in product_data_equivalence_inspection_result_schema represents the most detailed inspection results on a specific annotated model 3d equivalence criterion. An instance of this entity is created for each inspection and it includes information of inspected value and data elements on which the inspection was performed. If the exact location is required to know where an extreme inspected value was detected, instance_report_with_extreme_instances that is a type of annotated_model_3d_equivalence_inspection_instance_report that has location information on inspected data elements where non-equivalence defects were detected shall be used.
fund_cons.note: The type of data element to be inspected and the type of entity to represent the location of non-equivalence defect are controlled by each subtype of annotated_model_3d_equivalence_criterion defined in annotated_model_3d_equivalence_criteria_schema. The number of annotated_model_3d_equivalence_inspection_instance_report instances to be generated can be controlled by the attributes of annotated_model_3d_criterion_with_element_report_request defined in annotated_model_3d_equivalence_criteria_schema.
fund_cons.p: Users will specify thresholds to judge if a criterion is satisfied or not, which depends on business situation. They may or may not specify the accuracy for controlling precision of numerical calculation used in the inspection. But there are many cases that the information on the accuracy that is actually applied by the inspection is useful to interpret an inspection result. For this purpose, representation of the common accuracy applied to every inspection as well as the accuracy applied to inspection of specific criterion are provided in this schema.
